channel.title: WHATWG DOM Workstream-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG DOM Workstream

item.title: [ecmascript, dom] createTreeWalker: Use Best Practice Example
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/createTreeWalker

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example shows:

let currentNode;
while ((currentNode = treeWalker.nextNode())) {
  currentNode.data = currentNode.data.toUpperCase();
}

Also ...

while ((currentTextNode = textTreeWalker.nextNode())) {
  currentTextNode.data = encodeURI(currentTextNode.data.replace(/\s+/g, " "));
}

What did you expect to see?

It would be worthwhile to use the best practice in the above example as shown in the following section i.e.

while ((currentNode = treeWalker.nextNode()) !== null) {
  // ...
}

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

while: Using an assignment as a condition

But the real best practice is to go a step further and make the code even more clear — by adding a comparison operator to turn the condition into an explicit comparison:

const iterator = document.createNodeIterator(document, NodeFilter.SHOW_COMMENT);
let currentNode;
while ((currentNode = iterator.nextNode()) !== null) {
  console.log(currentNode.textContent.trim());
}

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [dom] createNodeIterator: Use Best Practice Example
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/createNodeIterator

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example shows:

let currentNode;
while ((currentNode = nodeIterator.nextNode())) {
  pars.push(currentNode);
}

What did you expect to see?

It would be worthwhile to use the best practice in the above example as shown in the following section i.e.

while ((currentNode = nodeIterator.nextNode()) !== null) {
  // ...
}

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

while: Using an assignment as a condition

But the real best practice is to go a step further and make the code even more clear — by adding a comparison operator to turn the condition into an explicit comparison:

const iterator = document.createNodeIterator(document, NodeFilter.SHOW_COMMENT);
let currentNode;
while ((currentNode = iterator.nextNode()) !== null) {
  console.log(currentNode.textContent.trim());
}

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-view-1, dom, uievents, pointerlock-2, fullscreen, DOM-Parsing, pointerevents3] MouseDown & MouseUp event articles should compare them to PointerDown & PointerUp
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseup_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Introduction, for Mouse Up, Pointer Up, MouseDown and PointerDown

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

"The mouseup event is fired at an Element when a button on a pointing device (such as a mouse or trackpad) is released while the pointer is located inside it."

The way I interpret this is, MouseUp happens when ANY of the buttons on the mouse is released. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then a mouseUp happens, even though the Right button is still down.

compare with the intro for PointerUp:
"The pointerup event is fired when a pointer is no longer active."

The way I interpret this is, PointerUp only happens when the last of all the buttons is released, so zero buttons are still pressed. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then no PointerUp happens, because the Right button is still down. Only when hte Right button is finally released, does the PointerUP event happen.

What did you expect to see?

Is what I just wrote right? Kindof vaguely implied by comparing the PointerUp and MouseUp articles. The MouseDown article is similllarly vague, although the POinterDown article nails down the issue better:

"The pointerdown event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons pressed to at least one button pressed. For touch, ...."

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/pointerevents/#dfn-chorded-buttons

Pointer Events do not fire overlapping pointerdown and pointerup events for chorded button presses (depressing an additional button while another button on the pointer device is already depressed).

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Most seriously, neither of the Mouse articles mention the Pointer events, and neither of the Pointer articles mention the Mouse events. These are important distinctions, and part of the reason why the Pointer events were invented.

Another example: the user can press the Left button down (MouseDown and PointerDown), then press and release the Right button, and no PointerDown or Up events will result, although MouseDown and Up events will happen. And, the user can then hold down both, and then release and press the Left button: Mouse Up and Down events will happen, but still no Pointer Up/Down events, because the whole time, at least one button remains pressed.

So, this relationship should be explained in one or another article(s). You can probably just expand the PointerDown article with such an explanation, and make sure the other three briefly describe it, and point to the PointerDown article for details.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/element/mouseup_event
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseup_event
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/element/mouseup_event/index.md
  • Last commit: 757f33e
  • Document last modified: 2023-06-26T04:47:03.000Z

item.title: [dom] Event.preventDefault: Inaccessible example
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The example that displays an error message for 2 seconds only

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The error message appears for 2 seconds and then it disappears.

The error message is inaccessible and sets the wrong method to write code.

It assumes the user has fully functional eyes.

It assumes that the user is sharp and can read the error message as fast as possible.

What did you expect to see?

The error message has to have the right semantics and does not disappear within 2 seconds.

I expect to see an accessible error message another example is used to demonstrate the event.preventDefault function (which on its own is anti-accessibility feature to begin with).

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault/index.md
  • Last commit: 3395959
  • Document last modified: 2023-04-07T05:59:30.000Z

item.title: [dom] getRootNode() documentation doesn't mention that it can return the element itself
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/getRootNode

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The documentation it is not clear that getRootNode() might return the element itself, if it doesn't have a parent.

What did you expect to see?

Clear statement that the parent of the element matters and also an example.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

From DOM Standard:

The getRootNode(options) method steps are to return this’s shadow-including root if options["composed"] is true; otherwise this’s root.

The root of an object is itself, if its parent is null, or else it is the root of its parent. The root of a tree is any object participating in that tree whose parent is null.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

document.createElement("div").getRootNode() // returns the div itself

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/node/getrootnode
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/getRootNode
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/node/getrootnode/index.md
  • Last commit: 312081a
  • Document last modified: 2023-04-07T06:19:30.000Z

item.title: [dom] More information about what HTMLCollection is replaced with
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCollection

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The second note on the page

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Note: This interface ... and only continues to be supported to not break code that's already using it. Modern APIs use types that wrap around ECMAScript array types instead, so you can treat them like ECMAScript arrays, and at the same time impose additional semantics on their usage (such as making their items read-only).

If HTMCollection is only supported as for already existing code, it would be helpful if the text referred to the preferred structure to use, or to some of the modern API which use etc....

What did you expect to see?

A magicNodeCollection is preferred to HTMLCollection as it is a .....
Examples of Modern APIs may point the reader to a useful place too.
Modern APIs, such as ?? and %%,

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [dom] Need to update lookupNamespaceURI() and createNSResolver()
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/createNSResolver

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Probably "Return value" and "Notes" should be updated

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

After whatwg/dom#1165, createNSResolver() should return the specified argument as is.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XPathEvaluator/createNSResolver should be updated as well.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/lookupNamespaceURI
This page should mention 'xml' and 'xmlns' prefixes handling.

What did you expect to see?

Align to whatwg/dom#1165

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [dom] addEventListener - which browsers/events default to passive
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Improving scrolling performance with passive listeners

Documentation of which browsers default to passive

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says "browsers other than Safari and Internet Explorer" default certain events to passive, suggesting Chrome and Firefox do this. But it seems to be Chrome and Safari that default those events to passive.

This is also mentioned in the description of the passive flag.

What did you expect to see?

I expect it to say "Chrome and Safari change the default value of the passive option to true for {wheel, mousewheel, touchstart, touchmove}".

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I looked up the history of the touch events defaulting to passive:

  1. 2017 https://developer.chrome.com/blog/scrolling-intervention/ Chrome says they will default touchstart, touchmove to passive
  2. 2018 WICG/interventions#18 (comment) Safari defaults touch events to passive

I've also tested the touchstart event myself to see if .cancelable is set, and

  • iOS 16.3/Safari: it's false (implying passive)
  • Android/Chrome 109: it's false (implying passive)
  • Android/Firefox 109: it's true (implying not passive)

Separately, wheel events:

  1. 2019 https://developer.chrome.com/blog/scrolling-intervention-2/ Chrome says they will default wheel events to passive, but also says that Firefox implemented the touchstart passive already (which doesn't match my tests)

I tested the wheel event to see if .cancelable is set, and

  • Mac/Safari 16.3: it's false (passive)
  • Mac/Chrome 109: it's false (passive)
  • Mac/Firefox 109: it's true (not passive)

So here too it seems to be Chrome and Safari that default to passive, not "browsers other than Safari and Internet Explorer".

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm happy to make a pull request but thought I should file an issue first.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/eventtarget/addeventlistener
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/eventtarget/addeventlistener/index.md
  • Last commit: a122e87
  • Document last modified: 2022-09-14T06:08:23.000Z

item.title: [dom] api.Element.replaceWith - Misleading details and prototype
item.content:encoded:
What type of issue is this?

Other

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

As you correctly link to the standard, replaceWith is a ChildNode mixin and not an Element method.

That means that even text nodes or comments can use replaceWith while not being instanceof Element.

This is rather a misleading link in MDN, but also changing it would kinda rot such misleading information, so something must change though, as the info is everything but reliable or accurate.

What browsers does this problem apply to, if applicable?

No response

What did you expect to see?

At least a link to ChildNode mixin, but also nothing strictly related to Element prototype.

Did you test this? If so, how?

document.createComment('').replaceWith ; // function
document.createComment('') instanceof Element; // false

Can you link to any release notes, bugs, pull requests, or MDN pages related to this?

https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-childnode

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/replaceWith

MDN metadata

MDN page report details
  • Query: api.Element.replaceWith
  • Report started: 2022-10-11T19:41:59.573Z

item.title: [html, dom] Event.returnValue: further deprecation information needed
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/returnValue

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Deprecated headline & Compatibility table

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Deprecated headline says that this feature is, obviously, deprecated, despite it being the only working feature across all browsers (preventDefault() doesn't work in Chrome)..
With return 'string' not also working in any browser as I've shown in this issue..

More information should be added, as, there's no way to show the unsaved prompt in chrome without this property (returnValue)..

Another problem is that, it's compatibility table isn't consistent with compatibility table in beforeunload event page

What did you expect to see?

More information on the situation, and not just run developers away from it without any working alternative around..
There's no other working solution other than it.. So, that has to be said, if you don't want to remove the Deprecated header.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/event/returnvalue
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/returnValue
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/event/returnvalue/index.md
  • Last commit: 1511e91
  • Document last modified: 2022-09-09T05:10:34.000Z

item.title: [dom] Issue with "AbortController": (missing info on behavior of .text() or .json() or other body promise)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This was missing information about whether calling the controller.abort() function would cause the promise returned from .json(), .text(), (or any of the body-downloading functions on the resolved Request object) to fail with Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request. (Chrome's behavior), From experimentation, it seemed that calling controller.abort() would cancel either the request promise or the body promise, so I think that detail should be added to save others the trouble.

Specific section or headline?

2 found pages: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortSignal
The section was the Note under the examples on these pages

What did you expect to see?

Details on the promise abortions returned from Response.prototype.text(), or .json(), or others.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yep, tested chrome console interaction when downloading a large file with Slow 3G network throttling. Test code:

var ctrl = new AbortController();
var res = await fetch('https://www.ledger-cli.org/3.0/doc/ledger3.pdf', { signal: ctrl.signal });
console.log('response received');
var data = await res.text();
console.log('text downloaded');

// ^ Executed the above, then after "response received" and before "text downloaded", manually executed:
ctrl.abort();

// Resultant behavior is that "text downloaded" never was displayed, and we received this:
// (x) Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request.
MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/abortcontroller
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/abortcontroller/index.md
  • Last commit: e89a324
  • Document last modified: 2022-01-12T16:54:36.000Z

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Document.getElementById()": link to xml:id doesn't include expected source snippet
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/getElementById

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This is a followup to #5124

The link in the bullet point

  • xml:id - has a utility method for allowing getElementById() to obtain 'xml:id' in XML documents (such as returned by Ajax calls)

was updated to point from a broken mdn link to a specification page on w3.org. However, this page doesn't actually have the promised utility method.

The source code that the link alludes to is actually present on the mdn page at internet archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20140408083257/https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/xml/xml:id
the code in question is a simple xpath method:

var getElementByIdWrapper = function (xmldoc, myID) {
        return xmldoc.evaluate('//*[@xml:id="'+myID+'"]', xmldoc, 
                function () {
                  return 'http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace';},
                XPathResult.FIRST_ORDERED_NODE_TYPE, 
                null).singleNodeValue;
};

I'm not sure if it makes sense to include this code in-line on this doc page, for most people it'd probably introduce more confusion, however in my specific case I was actually looking for this code and didn't understand why it wasn't available on the linked w3.org page.

Specific section or headline?

"See also"

What did you expect to see?

A link to some example code to get elements in an xml document based on the xml:id attribute

Did you test this? If so, how?

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/document/getelementbyid
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/getElementById
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/document/getelementbyid/index.md
  • Last commit: 2279e5a
  • Document last modified: 2021-09-14T18:08:09.000Z

item.title: [html, cssom-view-1, dom, WebIDL-1, FileAPI, uievents, pointerlock-2] Remove alert() from live samples
item.content:encoded:
window.alert() doesn't work cross-origin in Chrome any more, meaning that any of our live samples that rely on alert() are now broken.

See also #7553.

This is (I think) all the live samples in Web/API that use alert() in a live sample:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/attr/localname
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvasrenderingcontext2d/addhitregion
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document/querycommandstate
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/domexception/domexception
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventtarget/addeventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/file/name
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/keyboardevent/metakey
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/mouseevent
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/notifications_api/using_the_notifications_api
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/find
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/windoworworkerglobalscope/settimeout (fixed in #7560)

(I might have missed some).

We should replace all of these with some alternative. A common alternative is to write the output into an element in the example's document.
